adjective.description: Of a color at the end of the spectrum next to orange and opposite violet, as of blood, fire, or rubies.
examples: the sky was turning red outside

adjective.description: Communist or socialist (used especially during the Cold War with reference to the Soviet Union).
Stained with blood, or involving bloodshed or violence.
examples: red battle stamps his foot and nations feel the shock
their work is marked in red by the teacher
colors range from yellow to deep red
the reds and browns of wood
which dress - the black or the red?

noun.description: The situation of owing money to a bank or making a loss in a business operation.
examples: the company was $4 million in the red
small declines in revenue can soon send an airline plunging into the red
they would have been struggling to keep their businesses out of the red

phrases: Ever notice how that kind of rhymes with better dead than red?
This was particularly true during the McCarthy era of the 1950s when anti-Communist hysteria - better dead than red - reached great heights, especially in Catholic circles.
Having quite happily countenanced that MAD idea myself - better dead than red - I feel bound in conscience at least to give today's extremists the benefit of the doubt.
Tony suddenly grew angry and his face turned as red as a beetroot.
When I opened the door, his face was a red as a beetroot and I thought he was going to explode.
origin: Old English rÄ“ad, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch rood and German rot, from an Indo-European root shared by Latin rufus, ruber, Greek eruthros, and Sanskrit rudhira red.
